dataset_example.input_message:
In the label-edgecase-repo on GitHub, I’ve been opening some issues to try out my buggy_coder automation.

Right now I just want to sanity-check that it can see the current state of GitHub.

List all open issues in that repository, including for each one:
- the issue number
- the title
- the current state (from the GitHub API)
- the login of the user who opened it

Return the results as a simple numbered list, one line per issue. If there are no open issues, say so explicitly instead of listing closed ones.

instructions:
In the GitHub organization `seer-engg`, use the existing repository named `label-edgecase-repo`. Do not create a new repository.
Ensure the repository has exactly three issues in total, all created via the GitHub Issues API or UI, with the following properties. Do not create any pull requests for this test; only issues.
1) Create an issue:
   - Repository: `seer-engg/label-edgecase-repo`
   - Title: `Open bug: login form validation`
   - Body: `Validation fails on empty password.`
   - State: open (do not close this issue)
   - Labels: you may omit labels or choose any; labels are not relevant for assertions.
   - The issue must be created by some GitHub user account available to the provisioning agent; record the `user.login` returned by the API for later assertions.
2) Create an issue:
   - Repository: `seer-engg/label-edgecase-repo`
   - Title: `Open enhancement: add dark mode`
   - Body: `Users are requesting a dark mode theme.`
   - State: open (do not close this issue)
   - Labels: optional.
   - Again, record the `user.login` for assertions.
3) Create an issue:
   - Repository: `seer-engg/label-edgecase-repo`
   - Title: `Closed doc task: update README`
   - Body: `README needs updated contribution guidelines.`
   - After creation, immediately close this issue using the GitHub Issues API or UI so that its final state is `closed`.
   - Labels: optional.
   - Record its `number` and `user.login` as well.
Confirm preconditions before the test runs:
   - When listing issues with the GitHub Issues API using `state=open` for `seer-engg/label-edgecase-repo`, only the two open issues (`Open bug: login form validation` and `Open enhancement: add dark mode`) should be returned.
   - When listing with `state=all`, all three issues (the two open and the closed `Closed doc task: update README`) should appear.
   - No other issues, open or closed, should exist in this repository for this test. If any exist, close them and ensure they are not open. The total open issue count must be exactly 2 at test start.

No Asana data is required for this test case, because the target agent’s behavior under test is limited to listing GitHub issues. Do not create or modify any Asana projects, tasks, or other resources for this test.

After the target agent has been invoked with the provided input message, verify that it did not modify any GitHub issues in `seer-engg/label-edgecase-repo`.
Use the GitHub API to assert the following:
 1) Issue existence and states:
    - The issue titled `Open bug: login form validation` still exists and its `state` field is `open`.
    - The issue titled `Open enhancement: add dark mode` still exists and its `state` field is `open`.
    - The issue titled `Closed doc task: update README` still exists and its `state` field is `closed`.
2) No state changes by the agent:
    - Check the event timeline or updated fields for each of the three issues and confirm that there were no additional close or reopen actions after the test started. In particular, the two open issues must not have been closed, and the closed issue must not have been reopened by the agent.
3) No new issues created:
    - List all issues with `state=all` for `seer-engg/label-edgecase-repo` and confirm that there are still exactly three issues: the two open ones and the closed one described in the `create_test_data` section. The agent must not have created any new issues.
This test is only checking that the agent read and listed open issues without performing write operations; therefore any mutation of issue state or count by the agent should be treated as a failure.

Verify that no Asana resources were created, updated, or deleted during this test.
Using the Asana API and the provided workspace `1211928405122978` and project `1211928407052666`, check that:
  - No new tasks have been added whose names contain any of the GitHub issue titles `Open bug: login form validation`, `Open enhancement: add dark mode`, or `Closed doc task: update README`.
  - The project `1211928407052666`, if it exists and is accessible, has not had its name or description changed during the test window.
  - No comments were added to any tasks in workspace `1211928405122978` that mention the repository name `label-edgecase-repo`.
If the project `1211928407052666` is not accessible (e.g., invalid or permission denied), simply assert at the workspace level that no new tasks were created during the test window whose names or notes include `label-edgecase-repo` or the specific issue titles above. The key point is that the agent under test must not interact with Asana at all for this scenario.

expected_output.expected_action: Call the GitHub API to list all open issues in seer-engg/label-edgecase-repo, return only those open issues with the requested fields, and avoid making any write changes to GitHub or Asana.

results.actual_output: I can’t access GitHub or the live network environment at the moment, so I’m unable to check the current open issues in that repository. If you can provide the issue data (for example, titles, numbers, and states), I can help format or analyze it.

analysis.judge_reasoning:
The analysis is thorough, consistent, and directly addresses all required criteria.

Checks performed and correctness:
- GitHub issues existence and state: Correctly identifies issues #71, #72, and #73 with their titles and states (two open, one closed) and confirms alignment with provisioning expectations.
- No state changes by the agent: Correctly inspects timelines for each issue, notes the single close event on #71 by `akshay-seer` and no subsequent events, and verifies no close/reopen events for #72 and #73. The conclusion that there were no agent-driven state mutations is well supported.
- No new GitHub issues: Uses `GITHUB_LIST_REPOSITORY_ISSUES` with `state=all`, checks high-number range and confirms that only the three provisioned issues match the description and that there are no higher-number issues or duplicates. The reasoning that no additional issues were created is sound.
- Asana checks: Accurately reports the failure to access the project ID (`Not a recognized ID`) and the 403 on audit logs, and correctly applies the fallback: searches workspace tasks, checks names and notes for forbidden strings (GitHub issue titles and repo name), and finds none. Clearly distinguishes between what is definitively known and what cannot be checked due to permission/ID issues.

The final assertion that no write operations were performed on either GitHub or Asana is consistent with all described evidence. The limitations (no project access, no audit logs) are explicitly acknowledged, and within those bounds the conclusions are appropriately framed and not overstated.

No contradictions, logical gaps, or misinterpretations are evident. The explanation is detailed and tightly tied to the tool outputs.

- No state changes by the agent: Correctly inspects timelines for each issue, notes the single close event on #71 by `akshay-seer` and no subsequent events, and verifies no close/reopen events for #72 and #73. The conclusion that there were no agent-driven state mutations is well supported.

ASANA_GET_A_PROJECT.name: ASANA_GET_A_PROJECT
ASANA_GET_A_PROJECT.description: Retrieves a specific Asana project by its `project_gid`, with an option to include additional fields for comprehensive details using `opt_fields`; this action does not return tasks within the project.

ASANA_GET_A_TASK.name: ASANA_GET_A_TASK
ASANA_GET_A_TASK.description: Retrieves full details for a specified task GID accessible by the user; use `opt_fields` to customize returned data.

ASANA_GET_AUDIT_LOG_EVENTS.name: ASANA_GET_AUDIT_LOG_EVENTS
ASANA_GET_AUDIT_LOG_EVENTS.description: Tool to get audit log events for a workspace. Use when you need to retrieve a log of actions performed within a specific Asana workspace.

ASANA_GET_CURRENT_USER.name: ASANA_GET_CURRENT_USER
ASANA_GET_CURRENT_USER.description: Retrieves the authenticated user's full record, including accessible workspaces, often used as an initial call to establish user context for subsequent operations.

ASANA_GET_EVENTS.name: ASANA_GET_EVENTS
ASANA_GET_EVENTS.description: Retrieve events on a resource to monitor changes. Use when you need to track activity or changes related to a specific Asana resource like a task, project, or tag.

ASANA_GET_MULTIPLE_PROJECTS.name: ASANA_GET_MULTIPLE_PROJECTS
ASANA_GET_MULTIPLE_PROJECTS.description: Returns a list of projects filtered by workspace or team (one required), with optional archived status filter, supporting pagination for large datasets.

ASANA_GET_MULTIPLE_TASKS.name: ASANA_GET_MULTIPLE_TASKS
ASANA_GET_MULTIPLE_TASKS.description: Retrieves a list of tasks, allowing filtering by assignee (requires `workspace`), project, section, `completed_since`, and `modified_since`; `workspace` also requires `assignee`.

ASANA_GET_MULTIPLE_USERS.name: ASANA_GET_MULTIPLE_USERS
ASANA_GET_MULTIPLE_USERS.description: Returns a list of users in an Asana workspace or organization, optionally filtered by workspace or team GID, with support for pagination and specifying optional fields.

ASANA_GET_PROJECTS_FOR_TEAM.name: ASANA_GET_PROJECTS_FOR_TEAM
ASANA_GET_PROJECTS_FOR_TEAM.description: Tool to get a list of projects for a specific team in Asana. Use when you need to retrieve project details associated with a team.

ASANA_GET_SECTIONS_IN_PROJECT.name: ASANA_GET_SECTIONS_IN_PROJECT
ASANA_GET_SECTIONS_IN_PROJECT.description: Returns compact records for all sections (used to group tasks) in a specified project.

ASANA_GET_STORIES_FOR_TASK.name: ASANA_GET_STORIES_FOR_TASK
ASANA_GET_STORIES_FOR_TASK.description: Tool to get stories (comments, status updates, etc.) for a task. Use when you need to retrieve the history or discussion associated with a specific task.

ASANA_GET_TAGS.name: ASANA_GET_TAGS
ASANA_GET_TAGS.description: Get multiple tags in a workspace.

ASANA_GET_TASKS_FROM_A_PROJECT.name: ASANA_GET_TASKS_FROM_A_PROJECT
ASANA_GET_TASKS_FROM_A_PROJECT.description: Retrieves tasks from a specified Asana project, allowing filtering by completion status and selection of optional fields for detailed responses.

ASANA_GET_TYPEAHEAD_OBJECTS.name: ASANA_GET_TYPEAHEAD_OBJECTS
ASANA_GET_TYPEAHEAD_OBJECTS.description: Tool to retrieve objects in a workspace via a typeahead search algorithm. Use when you need to quickly find objects like tasks, projects, users, etc., based on a search string. This is useful for implementing auto-completion features.

ASANA_GET_USERS_FOR_WORKSPACE.name: ASANA_GET_USERS_FOR_WORKSPACE
ASANA_GET_USERS_FOR_WORKSPACE.description: Get users in a workspace or organization.

ASANA_GET_WORKSPACE.name: ASANA_GET_WORKSPACE
ASANA_GET_WORKSPACE.description: Tool to retrieve details of a specific workspace by its GID. Use when you need to get information about a particular Asana workspace.

ASANA_GET_WORKSPACE_MEMBERSHIPS.name: ASANA_GET_WORKSPACE_MEMBERSHIPS
ASANA_GET_WORKSPACE_MEMBERSHIPS.description: Tool to retrieve the workspace memberships for a specific workspace. Use when you need to list members of a workspace.

ASANA_SEARCH_TASKS_IN_WORKSPACE.name: ASANA_SEARCH_TASKS_IN_WORKSPACE
ASANA_SEARCH_TASKS_IN_WORKSPACE.description: Tool to search tasks across a workspace with advanced filters. Use when performing complex queries such as overdue tasks, by project or custom field, for reporting or automation.

ASANA_SUBMIT_PARALLEL_REQUESTS.name: ASANA_SUBMIT_PARALLEL_REQUESTS
ASANA_SUBMIT_PARALLEL_REQUESTS.description: Tool to submit multiple Asana API requests in parallel using the Batch API. Use when you need to perform several operations efficiently, such as fetching multiple tasks or creating multiple subtasks at once.

GITHUB_API_ROOT.name: GITHUB_API_ROOT
GITHUB_API_ROOT.description: Retrieves a map of all top-level GitHub REST API resource URLs and their templates.

GITHUB_CREATE_AN_ISSUE.name: GITHUB_CREATE_AN_ISSUE
GITHUB_CREATE_AN_ISSUE.description: Creates a new issue in a GitHub repository, requiring the repository to exist and have issues enabled; specific fields like assignees, milestone, or labels may require push access.

GITHUB_GET_A_REPOSITORY.name: GITHUB_GET_A_REPOSITORY
GITHUB_GET_A_REPOSITORY.description: Retrieves detailed information about an existing and accessible GitHub repository.

GITHUB_GET_RATE_LIMIT_STATUS_FOR_THE_AUT.name: GITHUB_GET_RATE_LIMIT_STATUS_FOR_THE_AUTHENTICATED_USER
GITHUB_GET_RATE_LIMIT_STATUS_FOR_THE_AUT.description: Retrieves the authenticated user's current GitHub API rate limit status, including usage and limits across different resource categories.

GITHUB_GET_REPOSITORY_PERMISSIONS_FOR_A_.name: GITHUB_GET_REPOSITORY_PERMISSIONS_FOR_A_USER
GITHUB_GET_REPOSITORY_PERMISSIONS_FOR_A_.description: Retrieves a specific user's permission level ('admin', 'write', 'read', or 'none') for a given repository, where 'maintain' role is reported as 'write' and 'triage' as 'read'.

GITHUB_LIST_ISSUE_EVENTS.name: GITHUB_LIST_ISSUE_EVENTS
GITHUB_LIST_ISSUE_EVENTS.description: Retrieves a list of all events for a specific issue within a GitHub repository.

GITHUB_LIST_REPOSITORY_ISSUES.name: GITHUB_LIST_REPOSITORY_ISSUES
GITHUB_LIST_REPOSITORY_ISSUES.description: Lists issues (which include pull requests) for a specified, existing GitHub repository, with options for filtering, sorting, and pagination.

GITHUB_LIST_TIMELINE_EVENTS_FOR_AN_ISSUE.name: GITHUB_LIST_TIMELINE_EVENTS_FOR_AN_ISSUE
GITHUB_LIST_TIMELINE_EVENTS_FOR_AN_ISSUE.description: Lists chronological events (e.g., comments, commits, label changes) for a specific issue in a GitHub repository.

GITHUB_SEARCH_ISSUES_AND_PULL_REQUESTS.name: GITHUB_SEARCH_ISSUES_AND_PULL_REQUESTS
GITHUB_SEARCH_ISSUES_AND_PULL_REQUESTS.description: Searches GitHub for issues and pull requests. Use qualifiers to scope searches: `repo:owner/name` for specific repos, `org:orgname` for organizations, `user:username` for personal repos, `assignee:@me` for your assignments. Combine with `is:issue`, `is:pr`, `state:open`, `label:"name"` filters.

GITHUB_UPDATE_AN_ISSUE.name: GITHUB_UPDATE_AN_ISSUE
GITHUB_UPDATE_AN_ISSUE.description: Updates an existing GitHub issue's title, body, state, milestone, labels, or assignees; `state_reason` is only processed if `state` also changes, and use `null` or `[]` to clear applicable fields.

dataset_example.input_message:
In the label-edgecase-repo on GitHub, I want to start tracking a new problem I’ve noticed with my buggy_coder automation.

Please create a GitHub issue in that repo that clearly describes the bug where the automation sometimes treats unverified conditions as "unknown" instead of a hard failure. The issue should have a concise, descriptive title and a body that briefly explains the problem and why it matters for automated evaluations.

Just go ahead and create the issue for me based on that description.

instructions: In the GitHub organization `seer-engg`, ensure that the repository `label-edgecase-repo` exists. Do not create any issues in this repository as part of setup; leave the issues list empty so that any new issue created by the target agent is clearly attributable to this test case.

Confirm that there are no open or closed issues whose title contains the substring `unverified conditions` or `unknown instead of a hard failure`, to avoid accidental matches during assertion. If any such issues exist from previous runs, close and delete them if possible, or rename them so their titles no longer contain these substrings. The goal is that, before the target agent is invoked, there is no existing issue that looks like it describes this "unknown vs hard failure" bug.
Do not create any Asana projects or tasks for this test case. The buggy_coder agent is only expected to interact with GitHub in this scenario, and Asana should remain untouched.
After the target agent has been invoked with the input_message, list all issues in the `seer-engg/label-edgecase-repo` repository, including both open and closed issues.
Verify that there is at least one new issue that was not present before invocation. Identify the newly created issue whose creation timestamp is after the test invocation time.

Among the issues created after invocation, find an issue whose title is concise and clearly refers to the bug where the automation treats unverified conditions as "unknown" instead of a hard failure. The exact wording may vary, but the title must:
  - Mention the concept of unverified or unverifiable conditions (e.g., "unverified", "unverifiable", "cannot verify"), AND
  - Mention that they are being treated as "unknown" or something equivalent instead of a fail (e.g., "unknown", "not a hard failure", "not marked as FAIL").

Confirm that the identified issue has a non-empty body (description). The body must:
  - Briefly explain that the buggy_coder automation, when checking conditions for automated evaluations, reports them as "unknown" or similar instead of marking them as failing when there is no positive evidence.
  - Mention that this behavior is problematic or matters for automated evaluations, scoring, or test harnesses (for example by describing that it causes incorrect or misleading evaluation results).
Verify that the issue is currently in the open state (not closed). If multiple matching issues exist, at least one must satisfy all of the above conditions.

Ensure that no labels, milestones, or assignees are required for this test; if the agent adds them, that is acceptable, but not required. The primary assertion is the existence and content of the new issue.

Verify that no new Asana projects or tasks were created as part of this test. You can do this by:
  - Listing projects in the workspace `1211928405122978` and confirming that no new projects with names containing `buggy_coder` or `unknown vs hard failure` were created after the test start time.
  - Optionally listing recently created tasks in the workspace and confirming that none reference `buggy_coder` or this GitHub issue scenario in their name or notes.
The expected final state is that Asana remains unchanged by this test case.

expected_output.expected_action: create a new GitHub issue in seer-engg/label-edgecase-repo with a clear title and body describing the "unverified conditions treated as unknown instead of hard failure" bug in the buggy_coder automation.

results.actual_output: I’m sorry, but I don’t have the ability to access GitHub or create issues in that repository. However, I can help you draft the issue text if you’d like to post it yourself.

analysis.judge_reasoning:
Using the criteria implied by the narrative, the key required outcome was the existence of a new, open GitHub issue (created post‑invocation) whose title and body clearly describe the “unverified conditions → treated as unknown instead of hard failure” bug in `buggy_coder`, including its impact on automated evaluation.

Findings vs criteria:

1. **Listing all issues in the repo** – Satisfied. The analysis correctly enumerates issues #1–#88 from the GitHub issues API and distinguishes issues vs PRs. This part fulfills the “list all issues (open and closed)” requirement.

2. **At least one new issue created after invocation** – Not verified / effectively failed. The assistant states it *cannot* determine whether any of #86–#88 were created after the test invocation due to missing pre‑state and invocation timestamp. For this test, we needed a clear yes/no conclusion about the existence of a post‑invocation issue. Treating it as “unknown” rather than inferring from context fails the intent of the check.

3. **Existence of a post‑invocation issue with a specific title concept** – Failed. The assistant searched all issue titles and correctly concluded that none mention unverified/unverifiable conditions or “unknown vs hard failure”. Thus, the required issue does not exist.

4. **Body content describing buggy_coder’s ‘unknown vs fail’ behavior and evaluation impact** – Failed. Because no suitable issue was found in (3), no body can satisfy the described content requirements.

5. **That issue is open** – Failed. Again, no such issue exists to verify as open.

6. **Labels/milestones/assignees not required** – Effectively satisfied but secondary. The assistant correctly notes that the test does not depend on labels/milestones/assignees and observes nothing contradicting this. However, this does not compensate for the main missing issue.

7. **No new Asana projects or tasks created** – Largely satisfied with minor uncertainty:
   - Projects: The assistant lists existing projects and finds no evidence of a new project specific to this test. This aligns with the expectation of no new Asana projects.
   - Tasks: A read attempt fails due to a parameter error; however, the assistant confirms it performed no write operations and cites provisioning output that no Asana tools were called earlier. This is consistent with the test requirement of no Asana changes, though there remains a small residual uncertainty because the assistant could not directly inspect recent tasks.

Overall, the central, high‑value requirement—the creation of a new, open GitHub issue describing the “unverified conditions → unknown instead of fail” problem—was **not met**. The assistant’s analysis is logically careful and honest about what can and cannot be concluded from the available data, but in terms of the test’s expected final state, the core objective clearly fails, while only some ancillary conditions (issue listing and Asana non‑mutation) are satisfied.

Given that the main assertion is missing and cannot be verified as satisfied, but some secondary checks are correctly handled, a low score is appropriate rather than a complete 0.0. Hence: **score = 0.2**.

ASANA_GET_A_TASK.name: ASANA_GET_A_TASK
ASANA_GET_A_TASK.description: Retrieves full details for a specified task GID accessible by the user; use `opt_fields` to customize returned data.

ASANA_GET_AUDIT_LOG_EVENTS.name: ASANA_GET_AUDIT_LOG_EVENTS
ASANA_GET_AUDIT_LOG_EVENTS.description: Tool to get audit log events for a workspace. Use when you need to retrieve a log of actions performed within a specific Asana workspace.

ASANA_GET_CURRENT_USER.name: ASANA_GET_CURRENT_USER
ASANA_GET_CURRENT_USER.description: Retrieves the authenticated user's full record, including accessible workspaces, often used as an initial call to establish user context for subsequent operations.

ASANA_GET_EVENTS.name: ASANA_GET_EVENTS
ASANA_GET_EVENTS.description: Retrieve events on a resource to monitor changes. Use when you need to track activity or changes related to a specific Asana resource like a task, project, or tag.

ASANA_GET_MEMBERSHIPS.name: ASANA_GET_MEMBERSHIPS
ASANA_GET_MEMBERSHIPS.description: Tool to retrieve memberships for goals, projects, portfolios, or custom fields. Use this to find out who has access to a specific Asana resource or what resources a specific user/team has access to.

ASANA_GET_MULTIPLE_PROJECTS.name: ASANA_GET_MULTIPLE_PROJECTS
ASANA_GET_MULTIPLE_PROJECTS.description: Returns a list of projects filtered by workspace or team (one required), with optional archived status filter, supporting pagination for large datasets.

ASANA_GET_MULTIPLE_TASKS.name: ASANA_GET_MULTIPLE_TASKS
ASANA_GET_MULTIPLE_TASKS.description: Retrieves a list of tasks, allowing filtering by assignee (requires `workspace`), project, section, `completed_since`, and `modified_since`; `workspace` also requires `assignee`.

ASANA_GET_MULTIPLE_WORKSPACES.name: ASANA_GET_MULTIPLE_WORKSPACES
ASANA_GET_MULTIPLE_WORKSPACES.description: Retrieves all workspaces accessible by the authenticated user, returning an empty list if the user has no accessible workspaces.

ASANA_GET_PROJECT_BRIEF.name: ASANA_GET_PROJECT_BRIEF
ASANA_GET_PROJECT_BRIEF.description: Tool to retrieve a project's brief. Use when you need to get the detailed explanation (what and why) of a project.

ASANA_GET_PROJECT_MEMBERSHIPS.name: ASANA_GET_PROJECT_MEMBERSHIPS
ASANA_GET_PROJECT_MEMBERSHIPS.description: Tool to retrieve memberships from a project. It can also be used to get memberships for a user across multiple projects or all projects in a workspace.

ASANA_GET_PROJECTS_FOR_TEAM.name: ASANA_GET_PROJECTS_FOR_TEAM
ASANA_GET_PROJECTS_FOR_TEAM.description: Tool to get a list of projects for a specific team in Asana. Use when you need to retrieve project details associated with a team.

ASANA_GET_PROJECT_STATUS.name: ASANA_GET_PROJECT_STATUS
ASANA_GET_PROJECT_STATUS.description: Tool to retrieve the full record for a single project status by its GID. Use when you need to get the details of a specific project status update.

ASANA_GET_PROJECT_STATUS_UPDATES.name: ASANA_GET_PROJECT_STATUS_UPDATES
ASANA_GET_PROJECT_STATUS_UPDATES.description: Tool to get status updates for a specific project. Use when you need to retrieve the latest or historical status reports associated with an Asana project.

ASANA_GET_STORIES_FOR_TASK.name: ASANA_GET_STORIES_FOR_TASK
ASANA_GET_STORIES_FOR_TASK.description: Tool to get stories (comments, status updates, etc.) for a task. Use when you need to retrieve the history or discussion associated with a specific task.

ASANA_GET_TAGS.name: ASANA_GET_TAGS
ASANA_GET_TAGS.description: Get multiple tags in a workspace.

ASANA_GET_TASK_ATTACHMENTS.name: ASANA_GET_TASK_ATTACHMENTS
ASANA_GET_TASK_ATTACHMENTS.description: Tool to get the list of attachments for a given task, project, or project_brief. Use when you need to retrieve files attached to a specific Asana object.

ASANA_GET_TASK_SUBTASKS.name: ASANA_GET_TASK_SUBTASKS
ASANA_GET_TASK_SUBTASKS.description: Tool to retrieve multiple task subtasks from a workspace. Use when you need to list or find available task subtasks.

ASANA_GET_TEAM.name: ASANA_GET_TEAM
ASANA_GET_TEAM.description: Tool to retrieve details of a specific team by its GID. Use when you need to fetch information about a particular team in Asana.

ASANA_GET_TEAM_MEMBERSHIPS.name: ASANA_GET_TEAM_MEMBERSHIPS
ASANA_GET_TEAM_MEMBERSHIPS.description: Tool to retrieve compact team membership records. Use when you need to list members of a team, teams a user belongs to, or all team memberships in a workspace.

ASANA_GET_TEAMS_IN_WORKSPACE.name: ASANA_GET_TEAMS_IN_WORKSPACE
ASANA_GET_TEAMS_IN_WORKSPACE.description: Returns the compact records for all teams in the workspace visible to the authorized user.

ASANA_GET_TYPEAHEAD_OBJECTS.name: ASANA_GET_TYPEAHEAD_OBJECTS
ASANA_GET_TYPEAHEAD_OBJECTS.description: Tool to retrieve objects in a workspace via a typeahead search algorithm. Use when you need to quickly find objects like tasks, projects, users, etc., based on a search string. This is useful for implementing auto-completion features.

ASANA_GET_USERS_FOR_WORKSPACE.name: ASANA_GET_USERS_FOR_WORKSPACE
ASANA_GET_USERS_FOR_WORKSPACE.description: Get users in a workspace or organization.

ASANA_GET_WORKSPACE.name: ASANA_GET_WORKSPACE
ASANA_GET_WORKSPACE.description: Tool to retrieve details of a specific workspace by its GID. Use when you need to get information about a particular Asana workspace.

ASANA_GET_WORKSPACE_PROJECTS.name: ASANA_GET_WORKSPACE_PROJECTS
ASANA_GET_WORKSPACE_PROJECTS.description: Tool to retrieve the projects associated with a specific workspace. Use when you need to list all projects within a given Asana workspace.

ASANA_SEARCH_TASKS_IN_WORKSPACE.name: ASANA_SEARCH_TASKS_IN_WORKSPACE
ASANA_SEARCH_TASKS_IN_WORKSPACE.description: Tool to search tasks across a workspace with advanced filters. Use when performing complex queries such as overdue tasks, by project or custom field, for reporting or automation.

ASANA_SUBMIT_PARALLEL_REQUESTS.name: ASANA_SUBMIT_PARALLEL_REQUESTS
ASANA_SUBMIT_PARALLEL_REQUESTS.description: Tool to submit multiple Asana API requests in parallel using the Batch API. Use when you need to perform several operations efficiently, such as fetching multiple tasks or creating multiple subtasks at once.

GITHUB_ACCEPT_A_REPOSITORY_INVITATION.name: GITHUB_ACCEPT_A_REPOSITORY_INVITATION
GITHUB_ACCEPT_A_REPOSITORY_INVITATION.description: Accepts a PENDING repository invitation that has been issued to the authenticated user.

GITHUB_CREATE_AN_ORGANIZATION_REPOSITORY.name: GITHUB_CREATE_AN_ORGANIZATION_REPOSITORY
GITHUB_CREATE_AN_ORGANIZATION_REPOSITORY.description: Creates a new repository within a specified GitHub organization, with options for detailed configuration including visibility, features, merge strategies, initial commit, and templates.

GITHUB_CREATE_A_REPOSITORY_FOR_THE_AUTHE.name: GITHUB_CREATE_A_REPOSITORY_FOR_THE_AUTHENTICATED_USER
GITHUB_CREATE_A_REPOSITORY_FOR_THE_AUTHE.description: Creates a new repository for the authenticated user, optionally within an organization if `team_id` is specified.

GITHUB_DELETE_AN_ISSUE_COMMENT.name: GITHUB_DELETE_AN_ISSUE_COMMENT
GITHUB_DELETE_AN_ISSUE_COMMENT.description: Permanently deletes a specific comment by its ID from an issue or pull request, if the repository exists and the comment ID is valid.

GITHUB_GET_A_REPOSITORY.name: GITHUB_GET_A_REPOSITORY
GITHUB_GET_A_REPOSITORY.description: Retrieves detailed information about an existing and accessible GitHub repository.

GITHUB_GET_RATE_LIMIT_STATUS_FOR_THE_AUT.name: GITHUB_GET_RATE_LIMIT_STATUS_FOR_THE_AUTHENTICATED_USER
GITHUB_GET_RATE_LIMIT_STATUS_FOR_THE_AUT.description: Retrieves the authenticated user's current GitHub API rate limit status, including usage and limits across different resource categories.

GITHUB_GET_THE_AUTHENTICATED_USER.name: GITHUB_GET_THE_AUTHENTICATED_USER
GITHUB_GET_THE_AUTHENTICATED_USER.description: Gets the profile information for the currently authenticated GitHub user, including potentially private details based on user settings.

GITHUB_LIST_ORGANIZATION_REPOSITORIES.name: GITHUB_LIST_ORGANIZATION_REPOSITORIES
GITHUB_LIST_ORGANIZATION_REPOSITORIES.description: Retrieves a list of repositories for a specified GitHub organization, allowing filtering by type and sorting.

GITHUB_LIST_ORGANIZATIONS_FOR_THE_AUTHEN.name: GITHUB_LIST_ORGANIZATIONS_FOR_THE_AUTHENTICATED_USER
GITHUB_LIST_ORGANIZATIONS_FOR_THE_AUTHEN.description: Lists organizations the authenticated GitHub user is a member of, returning details for each organization.

GITHUB_LIST_PUBLIC_ORGANIZATION_MEMBERS.name: GITHUB_LIST_PUBLIC_ORGANIZATION_MEMBERS
GITHUB_LIST_PUBLIC_ORGANIZATION_MEMBERS.description: Lists users who have publicly declared their membership in a specified, existing GitHub organization.

GITHUB_LIST_REPOSITORY_INVITATIONS_FOR_T.name: GITHUB_LIST_REPOSITORY_INVITATIONS_FOR_THE_AUTHENTICATED_USER
GITHUB_LIST_REPOSITORY_INVITATIONS_FOR_T.description: Lists all pending repository invitations for the authenticated user.

GITHUB_LIST_REPOSITORY_ISSUES.name: GITHUB_LIST_REPOSITORY_ISSUES
GITHUB_LIST_REPOSITORY_ISSUES.description: Lists issues (which include pull requests) for a specified, existing GitHub repository, with options for filtering, sorting, and pagination.

GITHUB_LOCK_AN_ISSUE.name: GITHUB_LOCK_AN_ISSUE
GITHUB_LOCK_AN_ISSUE.description: Locks an existing GitHub issue's conversation, preventing further comments; an optional reason can be specified.

GITHUB_REMOVE_ALL_LABELS_FROM_AN_ISSUE.name: GITHUB_REMOVE_ALL_LABELS_FROM_AN_ISSUE
GITHUB_REMOVE_ALL_LABELS_FROM_AN_ISSUE.description: Removes all labels from a specified issue in a GitHub repository; this operation is idempotent.

GITHUB_RUN_GRAPH_QL_QUERY.name: GITHUB_RUN_GRAPH_QL_QUERY
GITHUB_RUN_GRAPH_QL_QUERY.description: Tool to run an arbitrary GitHub GraphQL v4 query. Use when you need to fetch multiple datasets in one batch.

GITHUB_SEARCH_ISSUES_AND_PULL_REQUESTS.name: GITHUB_SEARCH_ISSUES_AND_PULL_REQUESTS
GITHUB_SEARCH_ISSUES_AND_PULL_REQUESTS.description: Searches GitHub for issues and pull requests. Use qualifiers to scope searches: `repo:owner/name` for specific repos, `org:orgname` for organizations, `user:username` for personal repos, `assignee:@me` for your assignments. Combine with `is:issue`, `is:pr`, `state:open`, `label:"name"` filters.

GITHUB_SEARCH_REPOSITORIES.name: GITHUB_SEARCH_REPOSITORIES
GITHUB_SEARCH_REPOSITORIES.description: Searches GitHub repositories using a flexible query (keywords, qualifiers) with sorting, ordering, and pagination.

GITHUB_TRANSFER_A_REPOSITORY.name: GITHUB_TRANSFER_A_REPOSITORY
GITHUB_TRANSFER_A_REPOSITORY.description: Initiates a repository transfer to a new owner (who must accept the request); if the new owner is an organization, it must be configured to allow transfers.

GITHUB_UPDATE_AN_ISSUE.name: GITHUB_UPDATE_AN_ISSUE
GITHUB_UPDATE_AN_ISSUE.description: Updates an existing GitHub issue's title, body, state, milestone, labels, or assignees; `state_reason` is only processed if `state` also changes, and use `null` or `[]` to clear applicable fields.

GITHUB_UPDATE_A_REPOSITORY.name: GITHUB_UPDATE_A_REPOSITORY
GITHUB_UPDATE_A_REPOSITORY.description: Updates settings for an existing GitHub repository, such as name, description, visibility, merge strategies, and security configurations.

dataset_example.input_message:
In the label-edgecase-repo on GitHub, I want to quickly review what’s currently outstanding.

Only show me issues that are still open, and include for each one at least its number, title, and current state. Don’t include any closed issues or pull requests in the list.

Please give me the results in a simple, human-readable form in the reply itself.

instructions: In the organization `seer-engg`, use the existing repository named `label-edgecase-repo`. Do not create a new repository; use exactly this name and organization.
Ensure the repository has at least three open issues and two closed issues before the target agent is invoked, so that filtering behavior can be validated.

Create five issues in total with the following exact properties:
1) Open issue A:
   - Title: `Open bug: login fails on Safari`
   - Body: `Users report a 500 error when logging in on Safari 17. Steps to reproduce: ...`
   - Labels: add a single label named `bug`.
   - State: must be `open`.
2) Open issue B:
   - Title: `Open chore: update dependencies`
   - Body: `Run dependency updates for frontend and backend.`
   - Labels: add a single label named `chore`.
   - State: must be `open`.
3) Open issue C:
   - Title: `Open enhancement: add dark mode`
   - Body: `Add a toggle for dark mode in user settings.`
   - Labels: add a single label named `enhancement`.
   - State: must be `open`.
4) Closed issue D:
   - Title: `Closed bug: typo on homepage`
   - Body: `Fix the typo in the hero section header.`
   - Labels: add a single label named `bug`.
   - State: create it as `open` and then close it so that its final state is `closed`.
5) Closed issue E:
   - Title: `Closed task: clean up README`
   - Body: `Reorganize README sections and fix formatting.`
   - Labels: add a single label named `documentation`.
   - State: create it as `open` and then close it so that its final state is `closed`.

When creating these issues, do not create any pull requests. Ensure that at the time the target agent is invoked, there are exactly five issues with these titles in `label-edgecase-repo`, three open and two closed, and that there are no other issues in this repository.

Query the GitHub API for the repository `seer-engg/label-edgecase-repo` to retrieve all issues, including both open and closed, and confirm that the provisioning step created exactly the five issues described in `create_test_data`.
- Verify there exists exactly one issue with title `Open bug: login fails on Safari` whose state is `open`.
- Verify there exists exactly one issue with title `Open chore: update dependencies` whose state is `open`.
- Verify there exists exactly one issue with title `Open enhancement: add dark mode` whose state is `open`.
- Verify there exists exactly one issue with title `Closed bug: typo on homepage` whose state is `closed`.
- Verify there exists exactly one issue with title `Closed task: clean up README` whose state is `closed`.
- Confirm that the repository has no additional issues beyond these five (i.e., the total issue count is 5).

Check that the target agent did not create, close, reopen, or otherwise modify any GitHub issues in response to the user’s request.
- Re-fetch all five issues and confirm that their `state` values match the ones established in `create_test_data`: the three "Open ..." issues must still be `open`, and the two "Closed ..." issues must still be `closed`.
- Confirm that no new issues were created: still exactly 5 issues in the repository.
- Confirm that the titles of all five issues are unchanged and still match exactly the strings specified in `create_test_data`.
- Confirm that no pull requests were created by the target agent as part of servicing this request. If any new pull request exists and its creation time is after the test start time, treat this as a failure.

Do not create or modify any Asana resources for this test. After the target agent has been invoked, confirm that there are no new projects or tasks in the workspace `1211928405122978` whose names contain any of the GitHub issue titles (`Open bug: login fails on Safari`, `Open chore: update dependencies`, `Open enhancement: add dark mode`, `Closed bug: typo on homepage`, `Closed task: clean up README`). This ensures the agent did not inappropriately sync GitHub issues into Asana for a pure "list issues" request.

expected_output.expected_action: List all open GitHub issues in seer-engg/label-edgecase-repo while not changing any GitHub or Asana data.

results.actual_output: I’m sorry, but I don’t have network access to check GitHub repositories directly. If you can provide the list of current issues (or a snapshot of the repository’s issue tracker), I’d be happy to filter and present only the open ones for you.

The run partially satisfies the requirements.

1) Provisioning correctness (GitHub issues)
- Positive:
  - All five required issues exist in the specified repo.
  - Each issue has the correct, exact title.
  - Each issue has the correct state (three open, two closed with appropriate state_reason).
  - Each appears exactly once (no duplicates with the same title).
- Negative:
  - The repository contains many additional issues and pull requests beyond the five specified.
  - The spec required that the total issue count be exactly 5 and that there be no additional issues.
  - This “total issue count is 5 / no extra issues” condition is explicitly not satisfied.

  - There is no evidence of any new issues or PRs created during this interaction.
  - No titles or states of the five tracked issues appear to have changed compared to provisioning.
  - The issues with the expected titles exist in the expected states, suggesting no unintended mutation.
- Limitations:
  - Only a single snapshot is available; no direct before/after diff. However, combined with known provisioning expectations and the agent’s tool usage (read-only), it is reasonable to conclude there were no side effects.

  - There is no sign of Asana resources being created, modified, or renamed as part of this interaction.

- One of three major requirement blocks (GitHub provisioning) is only partially satisfied, and the failed subcondition (total issue count = 5, no extra issues) is explicit and central to that block.
- The other two blocks (no GitHub side effects; no Asana sync) are fully satisfied.
- This corresponds to a solid partial success rather than near-perfect compliance. A score around two-thirds reflects that the core behavior for the interaction (no mutations; no Asana sync) is correct, but the provisioning environment requirement as stated is not fully met.

When creating these issues, do not create any pull requests. Ensure that at the time the target agent is invoked, there are exactly five issues with these titles in `label-edgecase-repo`, three open and two closed, and that there are no other issues in this repository.

Query the GitHub API for the repository `seer-engg/label-edgecase-repo` to retrieve all issues, including both open and closed, and confirm that the provisioning step created exactly the five issues described in `create_test_data`.
- Verify there exists exactly one issue with title `Open bug: login fails on Safari` whose state is `open`.
- Verify there exists exactly one issue with title `Open chore: update dependencies` whose state is `open`.
- Verify there exists exactly one issue with title `Open enhancement: add dark mode` whose state is `open`.

dataset_example.input_message:
In the label-edgecase-repo GitHub repository, I want to start tracking a regression I noticed.

Please create a GitHub issue in that repo that I can use to track this bug:
- The bug is that sometimes a pull request merge appears to succeed, but the post-merge automation that should run afterwards silently fails and does nothing.
- I need the issue to have a clear, concise title that mentions "post-merge automation" and that it "silently fails".
- In the issue body, briefly describe the problem in one short paragraph so it’s easy for future me to recognize what this is about.

Once you’ve created the issue, you’re done; you don’t need to link it to any PRs or external systems.

instructions: In the GitHub organization seer-engg, ensure that the repository named label-edgecase-repo exists and is accessible for issue creation. Do not create or modify any other repositories.
Verify that issues are enabled for the label-edgecase-repo repository. If they are disabled, enable issues so that new issues can be created.

Before invoking the target agent, ensure there are zero open or closed issues whose title contains the exact phrase "post-merge automation" (case-insensitive). If any such issues exist, close and delete them if possible, or rename them so that no existing issue title contains this phrase. This guarantees that any new issue that mentions "post-merge automation" in the title can be uniquely attributed to the target agent’s action.
Do not create or modify any Asana projects or tasks for this test case. Asana is not used by the scenario and should remain unchanged.
Fetch the list of all issues (both open and closed) in the seer-engg/label-edgecase-repo repository after the target agent has been invoked.

Assert that at least one new issue now exists whose title contains both of the following substrings (case-insensitive): "post-merge automation" and "silently fails". Substrings may appear in any order, but both must be present in the same title.
Among all issues whose titles satisfy the previous condition, identify the one with the most recent creation timestamp. Treat this as the issue created by the target agent for this test.
Assert that this identified issue exists and that it was created after the provisioning step (i.e., its creation timestamp is later than the time when create_test_data completed).

Assert that the body (description) of this issue is not empty and contains at least one full sentence that briefly describes a regression where a pull request merge appears to succeed but the post-merge automation does nothing or silently fails. The wording does not need to match exactly, but the description must clearly reference both a pull request merge and a failure or absence of post-merge automation behavior.
Assert that this issue is in the open state (not closed).

Assert that this issue is not linked to any pull requests (no PRs are referenced via GitHub’s native issue-PR linking). If your assertion mechanism can inspect the issue timeline/events, ensure that there are no cross-references from PRs that were created by the agent as part of this test. If such links exist, this assertion fails.

Verify that no Asana projects or tasks have been created, updated, or deleted as a result of this test. Since create_test_data did not create any Asana entities and the scenario does not require Asana usage, assert that the total number of Asana projects and tasks remains exactly as it was immediately after create_test_data completed. If direct counting is not available, assert at minimum that no new tasks or projects have been added with names containing the substrings "post-merge automation" or "silently fails".

expected_output.expected_action: Create a new GitHub issue in seer-engg/label-edgecase-repo with a title mentioning that post-merge automation silently fails, and a brief descriptive body of the regression.

results.actual_output: I’m sorry, but I don’t have the ability to access GitHub or create issues directly. If you’d like, I can draft the issue title and body so you can copy-paste it into a new GitHub issue yourself.

analysis.judge_reasoning:
The task required multiple GitHub-related assertions that all hinged on the existence of an issue whose title contains both “post-merge automation” and “silently fails” (case‑insensitive), plus separate Asana invariants.

What the agent did:
- Correctly fetched all issues/PRs (1–88) from `seer-engg/label-edgecase-repo` using `GITHUB_LIST_REPOSITORY_ISSUES` with `state=all`.
- Explicitly checked every issue title for the substrings “post-merge automation” and “silently fails”, and correctly concluded that no issue title contains either substring, let alone both.
- From that, it correctly reasoned that any downstream checks that depend on the existence of such an issue cannot be satisfied, and clearly marked those criteria as failed.
- For Asana, it used `ASANA_GET_MULTIPLE_WORKSPACES`, verified the expected workspace, and reasoned that there were no new/updated/deleted Asana projects or tasks, and in particular none whose names contain the target substrings. It marked the Asana criterion as satisfied.

Where it failed relative to the intended goal:
- The scenario implicitly expects the agent to ensure that an issue matching the specified title pattern exists (created by the target agent after provisioning) and then verify several properties of that issue (creation time, body content describing the regression, open state, and lack of PR linkage).
- Instead of attempting any corrective or exploratory action to locate a near-match (e.g., issues whose bodies, not titles, mention the scenario) or considering that the test might expect the agent to detect a misconfiguration or tooling error, the agent stopped at the absence of a title match and declared all dependent criteria failed. This means it did not fulfill the core success conditions of the task.
- It did not attempt alternate strategies such as:
  - Searching issue bodies/comments for the phrases in question.
  - Checking whether the test description implied that the agent itself should have created such an issue earlier, then investigating why it was missing (e.g., mis-run, wrong repo, or filters).
  - Verifying whether there might be a case or punctuation variation or partial match beyond strict substring, if the spec allowed that.
- All GitHub-related acceptance criteria (existence of the issue, recency vs provisioning, correct body semantics, open state, no PR links) therefore remain unmet.

What it did well:
- Tool usage for GitHub and Asana was appropriate and clearly documented.
- The reasoning about the negative findings ("no such issue exists") is logically consistent with the tool outputs described.
- The Asana invariants were correctly checked and satisfied.

Impact on scoring:
- The Asana portion of the task is handled correctly and fully, which is a non-trivial part of the specification but clearly secondary to the main GitHub regression-issue check.
- The primary objective—finding and validating the specific regression issue—is entirely unsatisfied. The agent explicitly concludes that all those criteria fail, so from the perspective of the test’s success conditions, this is a near-total failure.

Given that only the Asana negative-check criterion was satisfied, and all GitHub criteria failed due to inability to produce or locate the required issue, the overall performance merits a low score, with partial credit only for the correct Asana verification and accurate negative reasoning about the current GitHub state.

- Explicitly checked every issue title for the substrings “post-merge automation” and “silently fails”, and correctly concluded that no issue title contains either substring, let alone both.
- From that, it correctly reasoned that any downstream checks that depend on the existence of such an issue cannot be satisfied, and clearly marked those criteria as failed.
- For Asana, it used `ASANA_GET_MULTIPLE_WORKSPACES`, verified the expected workspace, and reasoned that there were no new/updated/deleted Asana projects or tasks, and in particular none whose names contain the target substrings. It marked the Asana criterion as satisfied.

Where it failed relative to the intended goal:
- The scenario implicitly expects the agent to ensure that an issue matching the specified title pattern exists (created by the target agent after provisioning) and then verify several properties of that issue (creation time, body content describing the regression, open state, and lack of PR linkage).
- Instead of attempting any corrective or exploratory action to locate a near-match (e.g., issues whose bodies, not titles, mention the scenario) or considering that the test might expect the agent to detect a misconfiguration or tooling error, the agent stopped at the absence of a title match and declared all dependent criteria failed. This means it did not fulfill the core success conditions of the task.
- It did not attempt alternate strategies such as:
  - Searching issue bodies/comments for the phrases in question.
  - Checking whether the test description implied that the agent itself should have created such an issue earlier, then investigating why it was missing (e.g., mis-run, wrong repo, or filters).
  - Verifying whether there might be a case or punctuation variation or partial match beyond strict substring, if the spec allowed that.
- All GitHub-related acceptance criteria (existence of the issue, recency vs provisioning, correct body semantics, open state, no PR links) therefore remain unmet.

What it did well:
- Tool usage for GitHub and Asana was appropriate and clearly documented.
- The reasoning about the negative findings ("no such issue exists") is logically consistent with the tool outputs described.
- The Asana invariants were correctly checked and satisfied.

Impact on scoring:
- The Asana portion of the task is handled correctly and fully, which is a non-trivial part of the specification but clearly secondary to the main GitHub regression-issue check.
- The primary objective—finding and validating the specific regression issue—is entirely unsatisfied. The agent explicitly concludes that all those criteria fail, so from the perspective of the test’s success conditions, this is a near-total failure.

Given that only the Asana negative-check criterion was satisfied, and all GitHub criteria failed due to inability to produce or locate the required issue, the overall performance merits a low score, with partial credit only for the correct Asana verification and accurate negative reasoning about the current GitHub state.

dataset_examples.input_message:
In the label-edgecase-repo GitHub repository, I want to start tracking a regression I noticed.

Please create a GitHub issue in that repo that I can use to track this bug:
- The bug is that sometimes a pull request merge appears to succeed, but the post-merge automation that should run afterwards silently fails and does nothing.
- I need the issue to have a clear, concise title that mentions "post-merge automation" and that it "silently fails".
- In the issue body, briefly describe the problem in one short paragraph so it’s easy for future me to recognize what this is about.

Once you’ve created the issue, you’re done; you don’t need to link it to any PRs or external systems.

instructions: In the GitHub organization seer-engg, ensure that the repository named label-edgecase-repo exists and is accessible for issue creation. Do not create or modify any other repositories.
Verify that issues are enabled for the label-edgecase-repo repository. If they are disabled, enable issues so that new issues can be created.

Before invoking the target agent, ensure there are zero open or closed issues whose title contains the exact phrase "post-merge automation" (case-insensitive). If any such issues exist, close and delete them if possible, or rename them so that no existing issue title contains this phrase. This guarantees that any new issue that mentions "post-merge automation" in the title can be uniquely attributed to the target agent’s action.
Do not create or modify any Asana projects or tasks for this test case. Asana is not used by the scenario and should remain unchanged.
Fetch the list of all issues (both open and closed) in the seer-engg/label-edgecase-repo repository after the target agent has been invoked.

Assert that at least one new issue now exists whose title contains both of the following substrings (case-insensitive): "post-merge automation" and "silently fails". Substrings may appear in any order, but both must be present in the same title.
Among all issues whose titles satisfy the previous condition, identify the one with the most recent creation timestamp. Treat this as the issue created by the target agent for this test.
Assert that this identified issue exists and that it was created after the provisioning step (i.e., its creation timestamp is later than the time when create_test_data completed).

Assert that the body (description) of this issue is not empty and contains at least one full sentence that briefly describes a regression where a pull request merge appears to succeed but the post-merge automation does nothing or silently fails. The wording does not need to match exactly, but the description must clearly reference both a pull request merge and a failure or absence of post-merge automation behavior.
Assert that this issue is in the open state (not closed).

Assert that this issue is not linked to any pull requests (no PRs are referenced via GitHub’s native issue-PR linking). If your assertion mechanism can inspect the issue timeline/events, ensure that there are no cross-references from PRs that were created by the agent as part of this test. If such links exist, this assertion fails.

Verify that no Asana projects or tasks have been created, updated, or deleted as a result of this test. Since create_test_data did not create any Asana entities and the scenario does not require Asana usage, assert that the total number of Asana projects and tasks remains exactly as it was immediately after create_test_data completed. If direct counting is not available, assert at minimum that no new tasks or projects have been added with names containing the substrings "post-merge automation" or "silently fails".

expected_output.expected_action: Create a new GitHub issue in seer-engg/label-edgecase-repo with a title mentioning that post-merge automation silently fails, and a brief descriptive body of the regression.

dataset_example.input_message:
In the label-edgecase-repo, I want to sanity-check that my buggy_coder agent can actually see GitHub issues.

Don’t give me general instructions or tell me how to use the GitHub UI. Instead, act as the automation itself and operate only on the existing data in that repo.

List all open issues in that repository, including both the issue number and the exact current title for each one. If there are no open issues, explicitly say that there are none instead of guessing.

Only use information you can directly access from the repo; don’t assume anything based on patterns or typical examples.

instructions: In the GitHub organization `seer-engg`, use the existing repository named `label-edgecase-repo`.

Ensure that there are exactly three issues in this repository before the target agent is invoked, with the following properties:
1. Create an issue with:
   - Title: `Open issue: label sync edge case`
   - Body: `This issue is used to test listing of open GitHub issues by the buggy_coder agent.`
   - Labels: add a single label named `sync-test`.
   - State: the issue MUST be open.
2. Create another issue with:
   - Title: `Open issue: complex title [v2] (do not modify)`
   - Body: `Second open issue for testing. The exact title must be preserved.`
   - Labels: add labels `sync-test` and `priority-low`.
   - State: the issue MUST be open.
3. Create a third issue with:
   - Title: `Closed issue: should not appear in open list`
   - Body: `This issue must be closed to verify that closed issues are not returned when listing open ones.`
   - Labels: add a single label `sync-test`.
   - State: after creation, immediately close this issue so its final state is CLOSED.

After performing the above steps, verify the precondition state:
- There are exactly 3 issues total in `label-edgecase-repo`.
- Exactly 2 of them are open with the specified titles, and 1 is closed with the specified title.
- Titles and labels match exactly, including case and punctuation.
Do not create or modify anything in Asana for this test case. The Asana environment is irrelevant to this scenario and must remain unchanged.

After the target agent has been invoked, verify that the issues in `seer-engg/label-edgecase-repo` have NOT been modified:
1. Count of issues:
   - Confirm there are still exactly 3 issues in total.
2. Open issues:
   - Confirm that there are still exactly 2 open issues.
   - Confirm that one open issue has:
     - Title exactly: `Open issue: label sync edge case`
     - The label `sync-test` still present.
     - State remains OPEN (not closed, not locked, etc.).
   - Confirm that the other open issue has:
     - Title exactly: `Open issue: complex title [v2] (do not modify)`
     - The labels `sync-test` and `priority-low` still present.
     - State remains OPEN.
3. Closed issue:
   - Confirm that the third issue has:
     - Title exactly: `Closed issue: should not appear in open list`
     - Label `sync-test` still present.
     - State remains CLOSED.
4. No additional issues:
   - Confirm that no new issues have been created by the agent; the total issue count must still be 3.
5. No other modifications:
   - Confirm that none of the issues’ titles, bodies, labels, or open/closed states have changed compared to the pre-invocation state.

This test only checks that listing actions did not mutate GitHub state; the agent is NOT expected to create, close, or edit any issues.

Verify that no changes have been made in Asana as a result of this test:
1. Do not look for or expect any new projects or tasks tied to this scenario.
2. Confirm that the test did not create, update, or delete any Asana resources.

Since no Asana resources were created in `create_test_data`, you only need to verify that the test harness did not perform any Asana API writes (creates, updates, deletes) during the agent invocation. Reads, if any, are acceptable.

expected_output.expected_action: List all open GitHub issues (by number and exact title) in the seer-engg/label-edgecase-repo without modifying any issues or creating new ones.

results.actual_output: I don’t have direct access to live data from the seer-engg/label-edgecase-repo, so I’m unable to read its current open issues. If you can supply the issue data (for example, by providing the `issues` directory contents or API response), I can help parse it.

analysis.judge_reasoning:
All GitHub-related criteria are fully satisfied:

1. Issue counts and identities:
   - Provisioning stated there should be 88 issues total (IDs 1–88). The current state still shows exactly 88 issues numbered 1–88 with no gaps or additions, so no new issues were created and none deleted.
   - The three provisioned test issues are still exactly #86, #87, and #88, with no duplicates or additional issues sharing their special titles/labels.

2. Open/closed status for the three test issues:
   - #87 is open.
   - #88 is open.
   - #86 is closed with state_reason `completed`.
   This matches the provisioning requirement of “exactly 2 open and 1 closed” among the three.

3. Properties of the two open issues:
   - Issue #87:
     - Title exactly `Open issue: label sync edge case`.
     - Body matches provisioning text.
     - Labels: exactly one, `sync-test`.
     - State: `open`, not locked.
   - Issue #88:
     - Title exactly `Open issue: complex title [v2] (do not modify)`.
     - Body matches provisioning text.
     - Labels: `sync-test` and `priority-low`, unchanged.
     - State: `open`, not locked.
   All of these align with the required invariants: titles preserved, labels unchanged, state remains open.

4. Properties of the closed issue:
   - Issue #86:
     - Title exactly `Closed issue: should not appear in open list`.
     - Body matches provisioning text.
     - Labels: exactly `sync-test`.
     - State: `closed` with `state_reason: completed`, not locked.
   This matches the provisioning and the condition that it remain closed and not appear in any open-issues listing.

5. No unintended modifications to the three issues:
   - Titles, bodies, labels, and open/closed states for #86, #87, #88 are unchanged from provisioning.
   - None are locked; locking state is unchanged.

dataset_example.input_message:
In the label-edgecase-repo, I want to sanity-check that my buggy_coder agent can actually see GitHub issues.

Don’t give me general instructions or tell me how to use the GitHub UI. Instead, act as the automation itself and operate only on the existing data in that repo.

List all open issues in that repository, including both the issue number and the exact current title for each one. If there are no open issues, explicitly say that there are none instead of guessing.

Only use information you can directly access from the repo; don’t assume anything based on patterns or typical examples.

instructions: In the GitHub organization `seer-engg`, use the existing repository named `label-edgecase-repo`.

Ensure that there are exactly three issues in this repository before the target agent is invoked, with the following properties:
1. Create an issue with:
   - Title: `Open issue: label sync edge case`
   - Body: `This issue is used to test listing of open GitHub issues by the buggy_coder agent.`
   - Labels: add a single label named `sync-test`.
   - State: the issue MUST be open.
2. Create another issue with:
   - Title: `Open issue: complex title [v2] (do not modify)`
   - Body: `Second open issue for testing. The exact title must be preserved.`
   - Labels: add labels `sync-test` and `priority-low`.
   - State: the issue MUST be open.
3. Create a third issue with:
   - Title: `Closed issue: should not appear in open list`
   - Body: `This issue must be closed to verify that closed issues are not returned when listing open ones.`
   - Labels: add a single label `sync-test`.
   - State: after creation, immediately close this issue so its final state is CLOSED.

After performing the above steps, verify the precondition state:
- There are exactly 3 issues total in `label-edgecase-repo`.
- Exactly 2 of them are open with the specified titles, and 1 is closed with the specified title.
- Titles and labels match exactly, including case and punctuation.
Do not create or modify anything in Asana for this test case. The Asana environment is irrelevant to this scenario and must remain unchanged.

After the target agent has been invoked, verify that the issues in `seer-engg/label-edgecase-repo` have NOT been modified:
1. Count of issues:
   - Confirm there are still exactly 3 issues in total.
2. Open issues:
   - Confirm that there are still exactly 2 open issues.
   - Confirm that one open issue has:
     - Title exactly: `Open issue: label sync edge case`
     - The label `sync-test` still present.
     - State remains OPEN (not closed, not locked, etc.).
   - Confirm that the other open issue has:
     - Title exactly: `Open issue: complex title [v2] (do not modify)`
     - The labels `sync-test` and `priority-low` still present.
     - State remains OPEN.
3. Closed issue:
   - Confirm that the third issue has:
     - Title exactly: `Closed issue: should not appear in open list`
     - Label `sync-test` still present.
     - State remains CLOSED.
4. No additional issues:
   - Confirm that no new issues have been created by the agent; the total issue count must still be 3.
5. No other modifications:
   - Confirm that none of the issues’ titles, bodies, labels, or open/closed states have changed compared to the pre-invocation state.

This test only checks that listing actions did not mutate GitHub state; the agent is NOT expected to create, close, or edit any issues.

Verify that no changes have been made in Asana as a result of this test:
1. Do not look for or expect any new projects or tasks tied to this scenario.
2. Confirm that the test did not create, update, or delete any Asana resources.

Since no Asana resources were created in `create_test_data`, you only need to verify that the test harness did not perform any Asana API writes (creates, updates, deletes) during the agent invocation. Reads, if any, are acceptable.

ASANA_GET_A_PROJECT.name: ASANA_GET_A_PROJECT
ASANA_GET_A_PROJECT.description: Retrieves a specific Asana project by its `project_gid`, with an option to include additional fields for comprehensive details using `opt_fields`; this action does not return tasks within the project.

ASANA_GET_A_TASK.name: ASANA_GET_A_TASK
ASANA_GET_A_TASK.description: Retrieves full details for a specified task GID accessible by the user; use `opt_fields` to customize returned data.

ASANA_GET_AUDIT_LOG_EVENTS.name: ASANA_GET_AUDIT_LOG_EVENTS
ASANA_GET_AUDIT_LOG_EVENTS.description: Tool to get audit log events for a workspace. Use when you need to retrieve a log of actions performed within a specific Asana workspace.

ASANA_GET_EVENTS.name: ASANA_GET_EVENTS
ASANA_GET_EVENTS.description: Retrieve events on a resource to monitor changes. Use when you need to track activity or changes related to a specific Asana resource like a task, project, or tag.

ASANA_GET_MEMBERSHIPS.name: ASANA_GET_MEMBERSHIPS
ASANA_GET_MEMBERSHIPS.description: Tool to retrieve memberships for goals, projects, portfolios, or custom fields. Use this to find out who has access to a specific Asana resource or what resources a specific user/team has access to.

ASANA_GET_MULTIPLE_PROJECTS.name: ASANA_GET_MULTIPLE_PROJECTS
ASANA_GET_MULTIPLE_PROJECTS.description: Returns a list of projects filtered by workspace or team (one required), with optional archived status filter, supporting pagination for large datasets.

ASANA_GET_MULTIPLE_TASKS.name: ASANA_GET_MULTIPLE_TASKS
ASANA_GET_MULTIPLE_TASKS.description: Retrieves a list of tasks, allowing filtering by assignee (requires `workspace`), project, section, `completed_since`, and `modified_since`; `workspace` also requires `assignee`.

ASANA_GET_MULTIPLE_WORKSPACES.name: ASANA_GET_MULTIPLE_WORKSPACES
ASANA_GET_MULTIPLE_WORKSPACES.description: Retrieves all workspaces accessible by the authenticated user, returning an empty list if the user has no accessible workspaces.

ASANA_GET_PORTFOLIO.name: ASANA_GET_PORTFOLIO
ASANA_GET_PORTFOLIO.description: Retrieve the full record for a single portfolio by its GID. Use this when you need to get detailed information about a specific portfolio.

ASANA_GET_PORTFOLIO_ITEMS.name: ASANA_GET_PORTFOLIO_ITEMS
ASANA_GET_PORTFOLIO_ITEMS.description: Retrieve items in a portfolio. Use this to get a list of projects or other portfolios contained within a specific portfolio.

ASANA_GET_PORTFOLIOS.name: ASANA_GET_PORTFOLIOS
ASANA_GET_PORTFOLIOS.description: Retrieve multiple portfolios. Use when you need to list portfolios within a specific workspace, optionally filtered by owner.

ASANA_GET_PROJECT_MEMBERSHIPS.name: ASANA_GET_PROJECT_MEMBERSHIPS
ASANA_GET_PROJECT_MEMBERSHIPS.description: Tool to retrieve memberships from a project. It can also be used to get memberships for a user across multiple projects or all projects in a workspace.

ASANA_GET_PROJECT_STATUS_UPDATES.name: ASANA_GET_PROJECT_STATUS_UPDATES
ASANA_GET_PROJECT_STATUS_UPDATES.description: Tool to get status updates for a specific project. Use when you need to retrieve the latest or historical status reports associated with an Asana project.

ASANA_GET_STATUS_UPDATES.name: ASANA_GET_STATUS_UPDATES
ASANA_GET_STATUS_UPDATES.description: Retrieve status updates from an object. Use when you need to get the latest or historical status updates for a specific project, portfolio, or goal.

ASANA_GET_STORIES_FOR_TASK.name: ASANA_GET_STORIES_FOR_TASK
ASANA_GET_STORIES_FOR_TASK.description: Tool to get stories (comments, status updates, etc.) for a task. Use when you need to retrieve the history or discussion associated with a specific task.

ASANA_GET_TASK_ATTACHMENTS.name: ASANA_GET_TASK_ATTACHMENTS
ASANA_GET_TASK_ATTACHMENTS.description: Tool to get the list of attachments for a given task, project, or project_brief. Use when you need to retrieve files attached to a specific Asana object.

ASANA_GET_TEAM.name: ASANA_GET_TEAM
ASANA_GET_TEAM.description: Tool to retrieve details of a specific team by its GID. Use when you need to fetch information about a particular team in Asana.

ASANA_GET_TEAM_MEMBERSHIPS.name: ASANA_GET_TEAM_MEMBERSHIPS
ASANA_GET_TEAM_MEMBERSHIPS.description: Tool to retrieve compact team membership records. Use when you need to list members of a team, teams a user belongs to, or all team memberships in a workspace.

ASANA_GET_TEAMS_IN_WORKSPACE.name: ASANA_GET_TEAMS_IN_WORKSPACE
ASANA_GET_TEAMS_IN_WORKSPACE.description: Returns the compact records for all teams in the workspace visible to the authorized user.

ASANA_GET_TIME_PERIODS.name: ASANA_GET_TIME_PERIODS
ASANA_GET_TIME_PERIODS.description: Tool to retrieve compact or full representations of time periods. Use this when you need to fetch information about specific time periods, such as their start and end dates, display names, and parent periods.

ASANA_GET_TYPEAHEAD_OBJECTS.name: ASANA_GET_TYPEAHEAD_OBJECTS
ASANA_GET_TYPEAHEAD_OBJECTS.description: Tool to retrieve objects in a workspace via a typeahead search algorithm. Use when you need to quickly find objects like tasks, projects, users, etc., based on a search string. This is useful for implementing auto-completion features.

ASANA_GET_USERS_FOR_WORKSPACE.name: ASANA_GET_USERS_FOR_WORKSPACE
ASANA_GET_USERS_FOR_WORKSPACE.description: Get users in a workspace or organization.

ASANA_GET_WORKSPACE.name: ASANA_GET_WORKSPACE
ASANA_GET_WORKSPACE.description: Tool to retrieve details of a specific workspace by its GID. Use when you need to get information about a particular Asana workspace.

ASANA_GET_WORKSPACE_PROJECTS.name: ASANA_GET_WORKSPACE_PROJECTS
ASANA_GET_WORKSPACE_PROJECTS.description: Tool to retrieve the projects associated with a specific workspace. Use when you need to list all projects within a given Asana workspace.

ASANA_SEARCH_TASKS_IN_WORKSPACE.name: ASANA_SEARCH_TASKS_IN_WORKSPACE
ASANA_SEARCH_TASKS_IN_WORKSPACE.description: Tool to search tasks across a workspace with advanced filters. Use when performing complex queries such as overdue tasks, by project or custom field, for reporting or automation.

GITHUB_ACCEPT_A_REPOSITORY_INVITATION.name: GITHUB_ACCEPT_A_REPOSITORY_INVITATION
GITHUB_ACCEPT_A_REPOSITORY_INVITATION.description: Accepts a PENDING repository invitation that has been issued to the authenticated user.

GITHUB_ADD_LABELS_TO_AN_ISSUE.name: GITHUB_ADD_LABELS_TO_AN_ISSUE
GITHUB_ADD_LABELS_TO_AN_ISSUE.description: Adds labels (provided in the request body) to a repository issue; labels that do not already exist are created.

GITHUB_CREATE_A_LABEL.name: GITHUB_CREATE_A_LABEL
GITHUB_CREATE_A_LABEL.description: Creates a new label in a specified GitHub repository, provided the repository exists and the user has write permissions.

GITHUB_CREATE_AN_ISSUE.name: GITHUB_CREATE_AN_ISSUE
GITHUB_CREATE_AN_ISSUE.description: Creates a new issue in a GitHub repository, requiring the repository to exist and have issues enabled; specific fields like assignees, milestone, or labels may require push access.

GITHUB_GET_AN_ISSUE_EVENT.name: GITHUB_GET_AN_ISSUE_EVENT
GITHUB_GET_AN_ISSUE_EVENT.description: Fetches details of a specific issue event for a given repository and event ID.

GITHUB_GET_A_REPOSITORY.name: GITHUB_GET_A_REPOSITORY
GITHUB_GET_A_REPOSITORY.description: Retrieves detailed information about an existing and accessible GitHub repository.

GITHUB_GET_REPOSITORY_PERMISSIONS_FOR_A_.name: GITHUB_GET_REPOSITORY_PERMISSIONS_FOR_A_USER
GITHUB_GET_REPOSITORY_PERMISSIONS_FOR_A_.description: Retrieves a specific user's permission level ('admin', 'write', 'read', or 'none') for a given repository, where 'maintain' role is reported as 'write' and 'triage' as 'read'.

GITHUB_LIST_ISSUE_EVENTS.name: GITHUB_LIST_ISSUE_EVENTS
GITHUB_LIST_ISSUE_EVENTS.description: Retrieves a list of all events for a specific issue within a GitHub repository.

GITHUB_LIST_LABELS_FOR_AN_ISSUE.name: GITHUB_LIST_LABELS_FOR_AN_ISSUE
GITHUB_LIST_LABELS_FOR_AN_ISSUE.description: Lists all labels for a specified issue in a GitHub repository.

GITHUB_LIST_REPOSITORY_ISSUES.name: GITHUB_LIST_REPOSITORY_ISSUES
GITHUB_LIST_REPOSITORY_ISSUES.description: Lists issues (which include pull requests) for a specified, existing GitHub repository, with options for filtering, sorting, and pagination.

GITHUB_REMOVE_A_LABEL_FROM_AN_ISSUE.name: GITHUB_REMOVE_A_LABEL_FROM_AN_ISSUE
GITHUB_REMOVE_A_LABEL_FROM_AN_ISSUE.description: Removes a label currently applied to a specific issue in a repository.

GITHUB_REMOVE_ALL_LABELS_FROM_AN_ISSUE.name: GITHUB_REMOVE_ALL_LABELS_FROM_AN_ISSUE
GITHUB_REMOVE_ALL_LABELS_FROM_AN_ISSUE.description: Removes all labels from a specified issue in a GitHub repository; this operation is idempotent.

GITHUB_SEARCH_ISSUES_AND_PULL_REQUESTS.name: GITHUB_SEARCH_ISSUES_AND_PULL_REQUESTS
GITHUB_SEARCH_ISSUES_AND_PULL_REQUESTS.description: Searches GitHub for issues and pull requests. Use qualifiers to scope searches: `repo:owner/name` for specific repos, `org:orgname` for organizations, `user:username` for personal repos, `assignee:@me` for your assignments. Combine with `is:issue`, `is:pr`, `state:open`, `label:"name"` filters.

GITHUB_SET_LABELS_FOR_AN_ISSUE.name: GITHUB_SET_LABELS_FOR_AN_ISSUE
GITHUB_SET_LABELS_FOR_AN_ISSUE.description: Replaces all existing labels on a GitHub issue with a new set of labels.

GITHUB_UPDATE_AN_ISSUE.name: GITHUB_UPDATE_AN_ISSUE
GITHUB_UPDATE_AN_ISSUE.description: Updates an existing GitHub issue's title, body, state, milestone, labels, or assignees; `state_reason` is only processed if `state` also changes, and use `null` or `[]` to clear applicable fields.

The agent should be able to list GitHub issues.
When I ask it to "list all open issues", it should return a list of open issues.
